thread.title: Longhorns taking infighting to media, Twitter
thread.title_full: Longhorns taking infighting to media, Twitter - San Antonio Express-News

author: Mike Finger
title: Longhorns taking infighting to media, Twitter
text:

A Texas A&M fan tweeted at Texas freshman defensive back Kris Boyd during the first half of TCU's humiliating beatdown, imploring him to transfer to the Aggies.
Boyd retweeted the fan's tweet at halftime.

The Longhorns can't even find a supportive shoulder in their fellow...
Image 18 of 18 Longhorns taking infighting to media, Twitter 1 / 18 Back to Gallery AUSTIN — With Texas reeling from its most lopsided defeat in 12 years and its worst start since 1956, Longhorns coach Charlie Strong began Monday by admitting, "Every day's a battle."
Within an hour, his players took it public.
With a series of interviews and Twitter responses painting the picture of a fractured locker room, UT upperclassmen called out younger teammates for a lack of work ethic and an abundance of oversharing on social media, and a couple of freshmen sniped back.
RELATED: Longhorns fans air their woes on Twitter
Two days after first-year cornerback Kris Boyd made national news for reposting Twitter messages from the locker room at halftime of UT's 50-7 loss at TCU, junior safety Dylan Haines didn't mince many words when talking about the team's youngsters.
"People need to grow up and take things more seriously," Haines said. "A lot of people aren't preparing the way we should be preparing."
After multiple reporters posted Haines' comments, freshman defensive end Charles Omenihu Quote: d one of the reports on his Twitter account and added the phrase, "Lol." In a separate post, he wrote, "People get in front of cameras and just talk (their) heads off. Always remember think before you speak."
RELATED: Longhorns led to slaughter by TCU
DeAndre McNeal, a freshman wide receiver, then chimed in with a long message on his account.
"We're supposed to be a team, but instead we're bashing each other," McNeal wrote. "If you don't want to be here at Texas then kick rocks. We haven't won ANYTHING to have people calling out others."
Asked if all of this is a sign of a divide between young and old players on the team, senior defensive back Duke Thomas tried to downplay it, but said, "There may be a little bit of a disconnect."
Strong said Boyd — who will be disciplined internally but will play against Oklahoma on Saturday — apologized to the team for his halftime Twitter use. Even though one of the messages was from a fan urging him to transfer to Texas A&M, Boyd — who reposts almost everything sent to him, including tens of thousands of messages — explained he didn't intend that as a slight against UT (1-4 overall, 0-2 in the Big 12).
Thomas said the only person in the locker room who saw Boyd on his phone at halftime was safety Adrian Colbert, who told Boyd to put it down. Thomas said during the second half, the Longhorns heard from fans in the stadium that Boyd had been on Twitter at halftime.
"When he did that, everyone felt disrespected," Thomas said. "(But) he didn't think anything was wrong with it."
Thomas said younger players are so "embedded" in social media that they don't realize how everything they post can be misconstrued. Junior defensive tackle Hassan Ridgeway said the social-media furor was overblown, and insisted there isn't a rift between UT's younger and older players.
But Ridgeway did acknowledge "players are getting on players," and said those being criticized need to handle it better.
"Sometimes people have to suck it up and understand where it's coming from," Ridgeway said. "A teammate is trying to help you out, not hurt you."
mfinger@express-news.net
Twitter: @MikeFinger
